item.title: Six additional judges of Delhi and Karnataka High Courts made permanent - Bar & Bench - Indian Legal News
item.description:
Six Additional Judges Made Permanent in Delhi and Karnataka High Courts

Published on: 23 Dec 2024, 3:55 pm

The Central government has officially appointed six additional judges from Delhi and Karnataka High Courts as permanent judges.

Key Points:

  • Union Minister of State for Law, Arjun Ram Meghwal, announced the appointments via Twitter.
  • Judges appointed to the Delhi High Court include: Justice Shalinder Kaur and Justice Ravinder Dudeja.
  • Karnataka High Court judges appointed include: Justice Ramachandra Dattatray Huddar, Justice Venkatesh Naik Thavaryanaik, Justice Vijaykumar Adagouda Patil, and Justice Rajesh Rai Kallangala (effective February 1, 2025, upon vacancy).
  • The Supreme Court Collegium, led by Chief Justice of India Sanjiv Khanna, recommended the appointments on December 12.

Notable Quotes:

“In exercise of the power conferred by the Constitution of India, the President of India, after consultation with Chief Justice of India, is pleased to appoint the following Chief Justices and Additional Judges as Permanent Judges in High Courts.” — Arjun Ram Meghwal

item.title: Government ends no-detention policy in KVs and JNVs, five years after diluting RTE Act - The Indian Express
item.description:
Government ends no-detention policy in KVs and JNVs, five years after diluting RTE Act

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

The Centre has scrapped the no-detention policy in Kendriya Vidyalayas and Jawahar Navodaya Vidyalayas, allowing students in Classes 5 and 8 to be held back from the current academic session.

  • The decision affects about 3,000 Central schools, including Sainik Schools and Eklavya Model Residential Schools.
  • Changes to the Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Rules now permit holding students back who do not meet promotion criteria after a re-examination.
  • A total of 18 states and Union Territories have already abolished the no-detention policy since a 2019 amendment to the RTE Act.
  • Schools are required to provide additional instructions and monitor progress for detained students.
  • The decision aims to enhance accountability within the education system.
“It is a very important legislation and a majority of state governments supported this proposal. It brings accountability in our elementary education.” - Former HRD Minister Prakash Javadekar

This policy shift has been met with mixed reactions as it seeks to balance the need for accountability in education against ensuring equal educational opportunities for all children.

item.title: Wife Imposing Her Friends & Family At Husband's Residence Against His Will Amounts To Cruelty: Calcutta... - Live Law - Indian Legal News
item.description:
Calcutta High Court Rules Against Wife for Imposing Guests on Husband

Date: 2024-01-15 | Source: Live Law

The Calcutta High Court has ruled that a wife imposing her friends and family on her husband at his residence without his consent amounts to cruelty.

“Such imposition of friend and family of the respondent on the husband at his quarter against his will… can definitely be constituted as cruelty…”
  • The appellant-husband filed for divorce citing cruelty due to the wife's actions.
  • The court noted that the wife's behavior made life unbearable for the husband.
  • There were disputes regarding the wife's alleged false accusations against the husband.
  • The bench emphasized that the unique circumstances of the couple's case must be considered.
  • The appeal by the husband was granted, resulting in a divorce decree.

Case: Mr. Dhiraj Guin Vs. Mrs. Tanusree Majumder | Case No: F.A. No. 1 of 2022 | Citation: 2024 LiveLaw (Cal) 283
